title: Bivariate Data Regression
text: code inputs variable names creates viewable data frame. Note analyses assume second variable criterion first variable predictors.
code: Predictor <- c(6, 8, 6, 8, 10, 8, 10, 9, 8, 7) Criterion <- c(7, 13, 11, 10, 13, 8, 11, 14, 12, 11) BivariateData <- construct(Predictor, Criterion)

title: Bivariate Data Regression
text: code obtains descriptive statistics data frame.
code: (BivariateData) |> describeMoments() Summary Statistics for the Data                  N       M      SD    Skew    Kurt Predictor  10.000   8.000   1.414   0.000  -0.738 Criterion  10.000  11.000   2.211  -0.617  -0.212 (BivariateData) |> describeCorrelations() Correlations for the Data            Predictor Criterion Predictor   1.000     0.533   Criterion   0.533     1.000

title: Bivariate Data Regression
text: section produces analyses overall regression model. code produce source table associated regression model.
code: (BivariateData) |> describeModel() Source Table for the Regression Model             SS      df      MS Model  12.500   1.000  12.500 Error  31.500   8.000   3.938 Total  44.000   9.000   4.889

title: Bivariate Data Regression
text: code produce confidence interval R Squared. code defaults 90% confidence intervals. can changed desired.
code: (BivariateData) |> estimateModel() Proportion of Variance Accounted For by the Regression Model            Est      LL      UL Model   0.284   0.000   0.555 (BivariateData) |> estimateModel(conf.level = .95) Proportion of Variance Accounted For by the Regression Model            Est      LL      UL Model   0.284   0.000   0.600

title: Bivariate Data Regression
text: code calculate NHST regression model.
code: (BivariateData) |> testModel() Hypothesis Test for the Regression Model              F     df1     df2       p Model   3.175   1.000   8.000   0.113

title: Bivariate Data Regression
text: section analyses regression coefficients obtained overall model.

title: Bivariate Data Regression
text: code provide table confidence intervals regression coefficients. code produce graph confidence intervals regression coefficients.  code defaults 95% confidence intervals. can changed desired. graph, possible plot just coefficients predictors (minus intercept) addition changing confidence level. comparison line region practical equivalence can also added.
code: (BivariateData) |> estimateCoefficients() Confidence Intervals for the Regression Coefficients                  Est      SE      LL      UL (Intercept)   4.333   3.794  -4.415  13.082 Predictor     0.833   0.468  -0.245   1.912 (BivariateData) |> plotCoefficients() (BivariateData) |> estimateCoefficients(conf.level = .99) Confidence Intervals for the Regression Coefficients                  Est      SE      LL      UL (Intercept)   4.333   3.794  -8.397  17.063 Predictor     0.833   0.468  -0.736   2.403 (BivariateData) |> plotCoefficients(conf.level = .99, line = 0, rope = c(-.5, .5), intercept = FALSE)

title: Bivariate Data Regression
text: code produce table NHST separately regression coefficients. case, coefficients tested value zero.
code: (BivariateData) |> testCoefficients() Hypothesis Tests for the Regression Coefficients                  Est      SE       t       p (Intercept)   4.333   3.794   1.142   0.286 Predictor     0.833   0.468   1.782   0.113

title: Bivariate Data Regression
text: code provide table confidence intervals standardized coefficient. places, code defaults 95% confidence interval. can changed desired.
code: (BivariateData) |> standardizeCoefficients() Confidence Intervals for the Standardized Regression Coefficients                Est      SE      LL      UL Predictor   0.833   0.468  -0.245   1.912 (BivariateData) |> standardizeCoefficients(conf.level = .99) Confidence Intervals for the Standardized Regression Coefficients                Est      SE      LL      UL Predictor   0.833   0.468  -0.736   2.403

title: Bivariate Data Regression
text: section provides analyses individual predicted values.

title: Bivariate Data Regression
text: code produces plot regression line (confidence prediction intervals suppressed).  code adds scatter data points regression plot.
code: (BivariateData) |> plotLine(interval = "none") (BivariateData) |> plotLine(interval = "none", points = TRUE)

title: Bivariate Data Regression
text: code provides estimates confidence prediction limits specific value Predictor (value=4). code plots confidence interval associated regression line labels interval specific value Predictor.  code plots prediction interval associated regression line labels interval specific value Predictor.
code: (BivariateData) |> estimateLine(value = 8) Confidence and Prediction Intervals for the Regression        Est   CI.LL   CI.UL   PI.LL   PI.UL 8  11.000   9.553  12.447   6.201  15.799 (BivariateData) |> plotLine(value = 8, interval = "confidence") (BivariateData) |> plotLine(value = 8, interval = "prediction")

title: Bivariate Summary Regression
text: code inputs variable summaries creates summary table. Note analyses assume second variable criterion first variable predictors. code creates correlation matrix.
code: Predictor <- c(N = 10, M = 8.000, SD = 1.414) Criterion <- c(N = 10, M = 11.000, SD = 2.211) BivariateSummary <- construct(Predictor, Criterion, class = "wsm") Predictor <- c(1.000, .533) Criterion <- c(.533, 1.000) BivariateCorr <- construct(Predictor, Criterion, class = "cor")

title: Bivariate Summary Regression
text: code confirms descriptive statistics summary tables.
code: (BivariateSummary) |> describeMoments() Summary Statistics for the Data                  N       M      SD Predictor  10.000   8.000   1.414 Criterion  10.000  11.000   2.211 (BivariateCorr) |> describeCorrelations() Correlations for the Data            Predictor Criterion Predictor   1.000     0.533   Criterion   0.533     1.000

title: Bivariate Summary Regression

title: Factorial Data Contrasts
text: code inputs variable names creates viewable data frame.

title: Factorial Data Contrasts
text: code obtains descriptive statistics two separate tables, corresponding simple effect. statistics can also obtained using simpler function call, procedure paralleled subsequent analyses.
code: (FactorialData) |> focus(FactorB == "B1") |> focus(Outcome~FactorA) |> describeMoments() Summary Statistics for the Data           N       M      SD    Skew    Kurt A1  10.000   8.000   1.414   0.000  -0.738 A2  10.000  11.000   2.211  -0.617  -0.212 A3  10.000  12.000   2.449   0.340  -1.102 (FactorialData) |> focus(FactorB == "B2") |> focus(Outcome~FactorA) |> describeMoments() Summary Statistics for the Data           N       M      SD    Skew    Kurt A1  10.000   8.000   2.449  -0.340  -1.102 A2  10.000   8.000   2.000  -0.417   0.735 A3  10.000   7.000   2.211   0.000   0.665 (Outcome ~ FactorA) |> describeMoments(by = FactorB) $B1  Summary Statistics for the Data           N       M      SD    Skew    Kurt A1  10.000   8.000   1.414   0.000  -0.738 A2  10.000  11.000   2.211  -0.617  -0.212 A3  10.000  12.000   2.449   0.340  -1.102   $B2  Summary Statistics for the Data           N       M      SD    Skew    Kurt A1  10.000   8.000   2.449  -0.340  -1.102 A2  10.000   8.000   2.000  -0.417   0.735 A3  10.000   7.000   2.211   0.000   0.665

title: Factorial Data Contrasts
text: code produce table NHST separately level factor. case, means tested value zero. Often, default test value zero meaningful plausible. can altered (often conjunction presented plot).

title: Factorial Data Contrasts
text: Identify 2 x 2 interaction interest (case, two levels FactorA existing two levels FactorB). Estimate plot interaction contrast (includes comparisons within simple effect).

title: Introduction

Simply put: 1) variable column, 2) observation row, 3) value cell. essential EASI interpret commands analyses. Raw data can entered standard vectors data frames, though EASI provides functions creating structures. case single-factor design (.e., multiple groups defined existing single variable outcome variable analyzed), data structured simple two-column frame , analyses (see Function Calls), formula can used indicate desire analyze groups. case repeated measures design, data arranged number columns matching number measurements , analyses (see ), entire frame passed function call. analyzing summary statistics instead raw data, EASI uses special frames containing rows variable group, columns sample size, means, standard deviations, special class identify whether -subjects within-subjects design. similar process used tables correlations.
code: (OneWayData) <- construct(Outcome, Factor) (RepeatedData) <- construct(Outcome1, Outcome2, Outcome3) (OneWayMoments) <- construct(Level1, Level2, Level3, class = "bsm") (RepeatedMoments) <- construct(Outcome1, Outcome2, Outcome3, class = "wsm") (RepeatedCorrs) <- construct(Outcome1, Outcome2, Outcome3, class = "cor")

title: Introduction
text: EASI offers general convention function names. function first comprised prefix (verb indicates procedure conducted). basic options (though elaborate functions also exist): describe - describe data model summary statistics estimate - estimate statistic confidence interval test - test estimates statistical significance standardize - standardize estimate provide confidence interval functions append appropriate statistical element (noun indicates statistics analyzed items provided). example: describeCorrelations - provides correlations among set variables estimateMeans - provides means confidence intervals set data Additionally, plot versions offer graphs descriptive statistics, estimates, confidence intervals . example: plotScatter - provides scatterplot data two variables plotMeans - provides graph means confidence intervals

title: Introduction
text: standard R syntax, function name followed parentheses variables analyzed relevant optional arguments (different confidence levels, null values, etc.). R versions 4.1 greater, native pipe operator can used instead standard syntax. , variables analyzed included first, followed pipe operator, function call (relevant additional arguments parentheses). format used throughout EASI. individual variables directly accessible (like dataset predefined) using subsets larger datasets (like analyzing specific variables groups), typically necessary identify data first select variables analyzed within data set. base R, accomplished using command (built data identification arguments). EASI, accomplished using focus command (many related uses well). Note function calls imply EASI uses general analysis workflow. simple cases, functions expect “Data |> Analyze” format, intermediate steps “focusing” specific variables groups. advanced cases (like factorial mixed designs), important elaborate “Data |> Describe |> Analyze” sequence (possibility “focusing” ).

title: Mixed Summary Traditional
text: code inputs variable summaries creates summary table. code creates correlation matrices.
code: Outcome1 <- c(N = 10, M = 8.000, SD = 1.414) Outcome2 <- c(N = 10, M = 11.000, SD = 2.211) Outcome3 <- c(N = 10, M = 12.000, SD = 2.449) MixedMomentsL1 <- construct(Outcome1, Outcome2, Outcome3, class = "wsm") Outcome1 <- c(N = 10, M = 8.000, SD = 2.449) Outcome2 <- c(N = 10, M = 8.000, SD = 2.000) Outcome3 <- c(N = 10, M = 7.000, SD = 2.211) MixedMomentsL2 <- construct(Outcome1, Outcome2, Outcome3, class = "wsm") MixedMoments <- combine(L1 = MixedMomentsL1, L2 = MixedMomentsL2) Outcome1 <- c(1.000, .533, .385) Outcome2 <- c(.533, 1.000, .574) Outcome3 <- c(.385, .574, 1.000) MixedCorrL1 <- construct(Outcome1, Outcome2, Outcome3, class = "cor") Outcome1 <- c(1.000, .408, .164) Outcome2 <- c(.408, 1.000, .553) Outcome3 <- c(.164, .553, 1.000) MixedCorrL2 <- construct(Outcome1, Outcome2, Outcome3, class = "cor") MixedCorr <- combine(L1 = MixedCorrL1, L2 = MixedCorrL2)

title: OneWay Data Advanced
text: code inputs variable names creates viewable data frame.
code: Factor <- c(rep(1, 10), rep(2, 10), rep(3, 10)) Factor <- factor(Factor, levels = c(1, 2, 3), labels = c("Level1", "Level2", "Level3")) Outcome <- c(6, 8, 6, 8, 10, 8, 10, 9, 8, 7, 7, 13, 11, 10, 13, 8, 11, 14, 12, 11, 9, 16, 11, 12, 15, 13, 9, 14, 11, 10) OneWayData <- construct(Factor, Outcome)

title: OneWay Data Advanced
text: shown elsewhere, standard EASI plot includes just confidence intervals means plus values.  enhance plot match implementations estimation statistics, can layered data plots, plausibility curves added, colors modified, values suppresed.
code: (Outcome ~ Factor) |> plotMeans() (Outcome ~ Factor) |> plotData(main = "Data, Confidence Intervals, and Plausibility Curves", method = "swarm", offset = -.15, col = c("darkred", "darkblue", "darkgoldenrod")) (Outcome ~ Factor) |> addMeans(values = FALSE, line = 9, col = c("darkred", "darkblue", "darkgoldenrod")) (Outcome ~ Factor) |> addPlausible(col = c("darkred", "darkblue", "darkgoldenrod"))

title: OneWay Data Advanced
text: Select levels comparison get simple plot confidence intervals values.  Get enhanced plot includes data along plausibility curve just comparison.
code: (Outcome ~ Factor) |> focus(Level1, Level2) |> plotComparison() (Outcome ~ Factor) |> focus(Level1, Level2) |> plotComparison(main = "Data, Confidence Intervals, and a Plausibility Curve", values = FALSE, ylim = c(0, 20)) (Outcome ~ Factor) |> focus(Level1, Level2) |> addPlausible(col = c("white", "white", "darkgoldenrod")) (Outcome ~ Factor) |> focus(Level1, Level2) |> addData(method="jitter", offset= c(-.15, .15), col = c("darkred", "darkblue"))

title: OneWay Data Advanced

title: Repeated Summary Traditional
text: analyses pairwise comparisons assume homogeneity variance make adjustments multiple comparisons (therefore effectively equivalent series paired samples t tests).

title: Repeated Summary Traditional
text: Obtain interval estimates pairwise comparisons. Provide traditional plot confidence intervals pairwise comparisons (including line represents difference comparisons).  Provide diffogram (plot means confidence intervals pairwise comparisons).
code: (RepeatedMoments) |> estimatePairwise(RepeatedCorr) Confidence Intervals for the Pairwise Mean Differences                         Diff      SE      df      LL      UL Outcome1 v Outcome2   3.000   0.596   9.000   1.651   4.349 Outcome1 v Outcome3   4.000   0.730   9.000   2.348   5.652 Outcome2 v Outcome3   1.000   0.683   9.000  -0.546   2.546 (RepeatedMoments) |> plotPairwise(RepeatedCorr, line = 0, values = FALSE) (RepeatedMoments) |> plotPairwiseDiffogram(RepeatedCorr)

title: Repeated Summary Traditional
text: Test pairwise comparisons statistical significance.
code: (RepeatedMoments) |> testPairwise(RepeatedCorr) Hypothesis Tests for the Pairwise Mean Differences                         Diff      SE      df       t       p Outcome1 v Outcome2   3.000   0.596   9.000   5.031   0.001 Outcome1 v Outcome3   4.000   0.730   9.000   5.479   0.000 Outcome2 v Outcome3   1.000   0.683   9.000   1.463   0.177

text: Get standardized effect sizes (confidence intervals) pairwise comparisons.
code: (RepeatedMoments) |> standardizePairwise(RepeatedCorr) Confidence Intervals for the Pairwise Standardized Mean Differences                            d      SE      LL      UL Outcome1 v Outcome2   1.617   0.466   0.703   2.530 Outcome1 v Outcome3   2.000   0.531   0.959   3.042 Outcome2 v Outcome3   0.429   0.333  -0.224   1.082

title: Repeated Summary Traditional
text: Relational intervals values (boxes graph) indicate whether two conditions statistically significantly different. analyses relational confidence intervals assume homogeneity variance make adjustments multiple comparisons. Provide estimates arelational relational intervals. Plot intervals.
code: (RepeatedMoments) |> estimateRelational(RepeatedCorr) Confidence and Relational Intervals for the Means                 M   RI.LL   RI.UL   CI.LL   CI.UL Outcome1   8.000   7.294   8.706   6.988   9.012 Outcome2  11.000  10.294  11.706   9.418  12.582 Outcome3  12.000  11.294  12.706  10.248  13.752 (RepeatedMoments) |> plotRelational(RepeatedCorr)

title: Repeated Summary Traditional
text: analyses post hoc comparisons assume homogeneity variance make adjustments multiple comparisons (based Tukey HSD procedures).

title: Estimation Approach to Statistical Inference
text: EASI R package implements features estimation statistics data visualization pipe-oriented framework. primary functions describe, estimate, test, plot confidence intervals means, mean comparisons, correlations, standardized effect sizes - within-subjects single-factor, factorial, mixed designs. functions can take either raw data summary statistics input. functions extend analysis capabilities offering summaries plots data, frequencies, densities, . features can combined produce images similar estimation statistics implementations. EASI extended DEVISE 2025.
